awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evolution of information processing in the Vibrio fischeri pheromone-signaling network
awd_abstract_narration:
Pheromone signaling controls many important bacterial behaviors, ranging from benign symbiotic relationships between bacteria and their hosts to colonization of human tissues and organs by bacterial pathogens.  The aim of this project is to understand how the local environment (e.g., the environment in the host) affects pheromone signaling and bacterial behaviors such as colonization. This project combines molecular-based microbiology methods with physical and mathematical tools to develop a more complete experimental and theoretical picture of this process. The project will enhance education by training graduate and undergraduate students to perform cross-disciplinary laboratory research. These research experiences will prepare the students for a wide range of careers in the biosciences. The project also includes a formal training experience for secondary science teachers, primarily from high schools with large numbers of students from under-served populations. 

The most important elements of Vibrio fischeri pheromone signaling are the LuxI/LuxR signal-synthase/receptor, which produces and detects a 3OC6 homoserine lactone (HSL) pheromone, and the AinS/AinR synthase/receptor system, which employs a C8 HSL pheromone to drive a different signaling cascade. The complexity of these systems is enhanced by the crosstalk generated by LuxR's recognition of both HSL signals, by the fact that both Lux and Ain are modulated in response to the environment, and by the presence of positive feedback in both the Lux and Ain cascades. The primary goal of this project is to understand how the system gathers and integrates information from its environment. The specific aims are to (i) understand how the pivotal regulator LuxR and its variants integrate information from the two HSL signals, (ii) identify the activation states of the broader pheromone-signaling circuitry and explore how environmental inputs lead to specific outputs, and (iii) test the hypothesis that the architecture of this signaling system allows spatially-heterogeneous environments to trigger population-wide responses over extended distance and time scales. The project will use cytometry and gene reporter methods to characterize LuxR interactions and system states. It will also use microfluidics and microscopy to explore signaling dynamics in heterogeneous environments. The results are expected to yield new insights into how bacteria use environmental cues to control population-level behaviors.

por.por_cntn:
Many species of bacteria are able to communicate by releasing chemical signals (pheromones) and detecting these in their environment. Communication may occur between members of a single bacterial species, or between different species. This exchange of chemical signals allows bacteria to control and synchronize complex behavior not only in response to environmental conditions but also in response to their own (or others') population density. The molecular pathways that bacteria use for this behavior, known as quorum sensing, are often complex and have features that are not well understood. They often produce and sense more than one type of chemical signal. They often produce these signals with positive feedback, so that the more signal is present in the environment, the more signal each cell produces and releases. In addition, there is often 'crosstalk' in the sensing of the different signals, so that pathways that sense different signals are interlocked or entwined, causing the information arriving from different signals to be partially merged or muddled. How these features interact to allow a bacterium to sense its external environment effectively and usefully is an interesting and important puzzle.

The aim of this project was to better understand how one important quorum sensing system, that of the marine bacterium Vibrio fischeri, processes the information received through its own complex sensing circuits. We studied how different aspects of the V. fischeri system affect the flow of environmental information through the sensing pathway, and how that affects the response of a colony of bacteria.

For example, we have studied how feedback enables these bacteria to communicate with each other over fairly large distances (a few centimeters). It has been hypothesized that when environmental conditions at one location activate the sensing system of bacteria in one location, they will secrete (owing to positive feedback) chemical signals that spread to nearby bacteria, eliciting a response from those nearby bacteria, causing further release and spreading of more signal molecules, which spread further outward, etc. In this way, if local conditions initiate quorum sensing response at one location in a colony, that response could spread outwards as a traveling pulse.

Our experiments showed that this behavior does in fact occur and it has some interesting properties. First, the response indeed can propagate as a wave that travels at constant speed. Second, the traveling wave has a threshold requirement, where the environmental stimulus at a location must be large enough, with enough cells present, to trigger the wave. Therefore a strong, localized stimulus can cause a pulse of behavioral response that will spread indefinite distances through a colony. Our experiments found quorum activation traveling as a wave, moving at nearly constant speed over centimeter distances, even for natural, unmodified strains of V. fischeri. These findings show how the feedback character of quorum circuits allows novel dynamics and surprisingly efficient long-range communication between bacteria. 

We also investigated how crosstalk between signals affects sensing by V. fischeri, which senses three different signals (autoinducers) using pathways that are partially entangled. We measured how mixtures of autoinducers (signals) presented to the cell affect the output response of the pathway, including the wide variability ('noise') in the behavior of individual cells. These experiments showed that the combinations of crosstalking signals at the input 'stretch' the range of responses that the population can produce. Rather than each signal eliciting a different type of response from the cell, the population overall has a continuum of possible responses, where mixtures of input signals tune the behavior of the population along that continuum.

We performed computer modeling to explore how the strength and type of crosstalk between signals affects behavior of the sensing circuit. This modeling has helped us to define and clarify essential properties of quorum sensing crosstalk for future study. The most important consequences of crosstalk turn out to arise in connection with positive feedback in signal production. Crosstalk synergizes with feedback to allow a richer set of behaviors for a cell that detects multiple types of signal. These studies have helped us to understand that while signal crosstalk in quorum sensing may muddle the flow of information through the sensing pathways, more broadly it expands the ways that a cell can adapt and respond to its environment.

Outcomes of this work have included the training of graduate and undergraduate students in biological physics and molecular microbiology, publication of research articles, and the presentation of findings at scientific colloquia and meetings. The work also provided science teacher training that included both summer laboratory experience and curriculum development opportunity.
